definitions.definition: near in space or time

examples.text: I had no idea the beach was so close.
Our new house is close to the school.
The children are close to each other in age.
She is looking for a job **closer to home**.
The tables were too close together.
Their birthdays are very close together.
This is the closest we can get to the beach by car.
We all have to work **in close proximity** *(= near each other)*.
Victory was tantalizingly close.

definitions.definition: knowing somebody very well and liking them very much

examples.text: Jo is a very **close friend**.
She is very close to her father.
She and her father are very close.
We're a very close family.
The two sisters seemed very close.
He was quite close to his older brother.

definitions.definition: near in family relationship

examples.text: **close relatives**, such as your mother and father, and brothers and sisters
The groom and his close family took their places.

definitions.definition: very involved in the work or activities of somebody else, usually seeing and talking to them regularly

examples.text: She has kept in **close contact** with the victims' families.
They have forged a **close** working **relationship**.
a retired army general with **close ties** to the military
The college has close links with many other institutions.
We work in close association with the ministry.
Their survival depends on close cooperation.
Even their **closest allies **were shocked by the move.
He is one of the prime minister's closest advisers.
We are in close touch with the police.

definitions.definition: careful and complete

examples.text: Take a **close look** at this photograph.
On closer examination, the painting proved to be a fake.
A close inspection reveals stunning attention to detail.
Pay **close attention** to what I am telling you.

definitions.definition: almost in a particular state; likely to do something soon
definitions.sensetop: close to somethingclose to doing something

examples.text: The airline is close to collapse.
He was close to tears.
The species is **dangerously close** to extinction.
The new library is close to completion.
She knew she was close to death.
We are close to signing the agreement.

definitions.definition: very similar to something else or to an amount

examples.text: There's a **close resemblance between them** *(= they look very similar)*.
This movie is about as close to perfect as you could wish for.
Their chances of winning are close to zero.
His feeling for her was close to hatred.
The total was close to 20% of the workforce.
It was **the closest thing to** a home she had ever known.
We tried to match the colours, but this is the closest we could get.
The unemployment rate was close to 20% of the workforce.
The book bears a close resemblance to her earlier work.

definitions.definition: won by only a small amount or distance

examples.text: a close match/contest/election
It was **pretty close** but we lost.
Our team came a **close second** *(= nearly won)*.
No one expected such a close finish.
The game was closer than the score suggests.
The result is going to be **too close to call** *(= either side may win)*.
The organizers of the race are predicting a close finish.
It's a desperately close race—I can't quite see who is ahead.
The California election looks too close to call as voters go to the polls.
I think it's going to be close.

definitions.definition: used to describe something, usually a dangerous or unpleasant situation, that nearly happens

examples.text: Phew! That was close—that car nearly hit us.
We caught the bus in the end but it was close *(= we nearly missed it)*.

definitions.definition: with little or no space in between

examples.text: over 1 000 pages of close print
The soldiers advanced in close formation.

definitions.definition: cut very short, near to the skin

examples.text: a **close haircut/shave**

definitions.definition: carefully guarded

examples.text: The donor's identity is a **close secret**.
She was kept under **close arrest**.

definitions.definition: warm in an uncomfortable way because there does not seem to be enough fresh air

examples.text: It’s very close today—I think there’s going to be a storm.

definitions.definition: not willing to give personal information about yourself

examples.text: He was close about his past.

definitions.definition: not liking to spend money

examples.text: She's always been very close with her money.

definitions.definition: produced with part of the tongue in the highest possible position without limiting the flow of air
very near

examples.text: fighting at close quarters

definitions.definition: from only a short distance away

examples.text: The president was shot at close range.
She scored from close range.

definitions.definition: close to you in time or distance

examples.text: Help was at hand.
The property is ideally located with all local amenities close at hand.

definitions.definition: used to tell somebody that their attempt or guess was almost but not quite successful
a situation in which you only just manage to avoid an accident, etc.

examples.text: He had a close shave when his brakes failed on the mountain road.

definitions.definition: a situation in which success or failure is equally possible

examples.text: We got him out in the end, but it was a close thing.

definitions.definition: having a lot of importance and interest for somebody
if a remark or topic of discussion is close to home, it is accurate or connected with you in a way that makes you uncomfortable or embarrassed

examples.text: Her remarks about me were embarrassingly close to home.

definitions.definition: that involves somebody directly

examples.text: The next year tragedy struck much closer to home.

definitions.definition: to watch somebody/something carefully

examples.text: Over the next few months we will keep a close eye on sales.

definitions.definition: so near that it is uncomfortable or dangerous

examples.text: When she leaves the stage, the fans can get a little too close for comfort.
They got the win but it was a tight match, definitely too close for comfort.

definitions.definition: physically very close to somebody; getting to know them well

examples.text: **Get up close and personal** with the koalas at the San Diego Zoo.
For the last 30 years, I’ve been up close and personal with people whose lives were in crisis.

wordOrigin: Middle English: from Old French clos (as noun and adjective), from Latin clausum ‘enclosure’ and clausus ‘closed’, past participle of claudere.
